avalancheActivity.comment:
In the last two days mostly small wind slabs formed especially in places that are protected from the wind. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind they will increase in size in the afternoon. These can to an increasing extent be released, even by small loads in isolated cases, but they will be small in most cases, especially on extremely steep slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Even a small avalanche can sweep people along and give rise to falls.

As a consequence of new snow and wind dry avalanches are possible on Monday, even medium-sized ones.
avalancheActivity.highlights: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard crust. Wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of new snow and wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent towards the evening.

snowpackStructure.comment:
In some regions up to 20 cm of snow, and up to 40 cm in some localities, will fall until Monday.
The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow significantly. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Monday. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a resilient melt-freeze crust.
Above approximately 2100 m a lot of snow is lying.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good over a wide area. The backcountry touring conditions are mostly favourable.
As the temperature drops hardly any more moist and wet avalanches are possible.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
avalancheActivity.highlights: There is a danger of falling on the hard crust. Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

snowpackStructure.comment:
In some localities 10 to 30 cm of snow, but less in some localities, will fall until Monday above approximately 2000 m.

The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will hardly soften at all.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase on Monday.
